title: Dell CFO Leads Charge to Pay Down Debt Load
text:
Dell Technologies Inc. finance chief Tom Sweet is focusing on driving down a mountain of debt amid scrutiny from investors and analysts.

The personal-computer maker and data-storage company plans to have conversations with credit rating firms in the next 12 to 18 months that could result in an investment-grade corporate credit rating for Dell’s core debt, Mr. Sweet said Thursday in an interview.

“Investment grade allows us better financial flexibility, access to the commercial paper market and access to a better economic framework from a debt perspective,” Mr. Sweet said.

Dell’s $67 billion merger with EMC Corp. in 2016, the largest-ever technology takeover, saddled the company with substantial debt. Before the 2016 deal, principal debt totaled $13.48 billion. Since then, Dell’s total principal debt has risen to $52.6 billion, nearly 70% of which is classified as core debt, according to the company’s second-quarter report in August. Dell said it has repaid $12.3 billion in core debt since the deal.

The Round Rock, Texas-based company returned to trading in the public markets in December, five years after going private. Relisting has resulted in increased scrutiny into the company’s financial performance.

Investors and analysts have frequently told Mr. Sweet over the past year that Dell’s level of debt is “worrisome,” he said at an investor conference Thursday. “That message has not been lost on us,” Mr. Sweet said, “but it’s also a message that we had been working on pretty consistently for the last three years.”

To delever the balance sheet, Dell plans to continue generating strong cash flow, Mr. Sweet said. The company expects core debt to fall to $30 billion by fiscal 2021 and its leverage ratio—which the company calculates as core debt divided by core earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization—to decrease to between 2 and 3 times Ebitda by the end of fiscal year 2021, down from 4.2 times Ebitda in fiscal 2019.

Dell’s corporate credit quality has been rated as non-investment grade by S&P Global Inc., Moody’s Investors Service and Fitch Ratings Inc. since 2013, when founder Michael Dell and private-equity firm Silver Lake took the company private. Fitch has a negative outlook for Dell, whereas S&P revised its outlook from negative to stable earlier this month.

“The long-term debt amount will be determined by growth,” said David Tsui, senior director in the corporate ratings group at S&P Global who follows Dell. “If the company is growing and the Ebitda base continues to grow, the gross debt amount can be higher.”

Dell has continued investing in research and development and, through its majority ownership in software firm VMware Inc., has pursued acquisitions. The company is continuing to look for investment opportunities, Mr. Sweet said.

Headwinds for the company include import tariffs imposed by the U.S. and China and a slowdown in technology spending. As a result, shipping costs have risen and Dell was forced to raise prices on some data-center products, Mr. Sweet said.

Still, Dell booked record revenue in its client-solutions group in the latest quarter. The unit, which sells items such as PCs and notebooks, notched revenue of $11.75 billion, up 6% from the prior year.

Mr. Sweet joined the company in 1997 and was named CFO in 2014. In recent months he has spent a great deal of time with investors to articulate the company’s strategy, he said.

“Trying to make sure our investor base understands that we’re running the business for the long term and are not here to optimize any particular quarter has taken up a fair amount of my time,” Mr. Sweet said.

Write to Mark Maurer at mark.maurer@wsj.com
description: Dell Technologies Inc. finance chief Tom Sweet is focusing on driving down a mountain of debt amid scrutiny from investors and analysts.
